pageData.text: This investigation is an introduction to the study of anatomy and physiology. By dissecting a preserved rat specimen, the student will explore the complexity of the various organ systems, gain experience in correct dissection procedures, and apply the fundamental terminology of anatomical discourse.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Large cucumber (also acceptable— zucchini squash, banana)
Permanent marker
Paper towels
70% isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) or other non-bleach disinfectant
Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos
Ruler
Opaque trash bag

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 20 minutes 
Activity 1: Directional Terms and Introduction to Dissection Techniques – 20 minutes 
Activity 2: External Anatomy of the Rat – 20 minutes 
Activity 3: Opening and Examining the Ventral Body Cavity – 20 minutes

text: Apply basic anatomical descriptive terminology to the process of dissection.
Use the essential tools and techniques for performing a dissection.
Identify the major structures of mammalian organs and organ systems, and describe their primary functions.

pageData.text: On fictional crime shows, mysterious deaths and strange crimes are solved with technology. In reality, such complex crimes are often solved by medical examiners performing detailed forensic autopsies. An example of this occurred a few years ago with the death of a child. Upon initial examination, the child appeared to be healthy and there were no visible signs of abuse. When the medical examiner performed the forensic autopsy, he discovered a contusion that was visible on the skin. As he was trying to figure out what caused the contusion, the medical examiner discovered iron in the child’s lungs. Although iron in the lungs can be caused by many different diseases, none of the other organs were afflicted. This led the examiner to conclude the child died from repetitive asphyxia, which caused blood cells to collect in the lungs. When the primary caregiver was interviewed, they admitted that the child was disciplined by squeezing the chest until the child passed out. The last time this occurred the child was asphyxiated so long he stopped breathing for the last time. The medical examiner stated that there were no high-tech procedures used to solve the crime, just old-fashioned detective work1.

1Spencer, S. (2018). A retired medical examiner on one of his most unusual autopsies. A &E.
https://www.aetv.com/real-crime/medical-examiner-autopsy-murder-shocking-surprising-unusual-cases

pageData.altText: Three metal autopsy tables in a medical examination room.
pageData.desc: Three metal autopsy tables in a medical examination room.

pageData.text: One of the greatest challenges in learning anatomy and physiology is the extensive vocabulary. In this activity, a preserved rat is examined and dissected to understand the relationship between structure (anatomy) and function (physiology). Dissection provides an opportunity to learn the names of and the relationships between the various structures.The terms in and are consistently used in directing dissection procedures and describing the locations and orientations of anatomical structures. These terms refer to the specimen in its For a human, this means the is erect, with the arms at the sides and the palms of the hands facing forward, and the feet spaced slightly apart. A rat in the comparable position for dissection has its abdomen facing up toward the observer.

Note: All mammalian bodies are similar in structure and function, so the terminology used to refer to anatomical locations in various mammalian species is likewise similar. However, there are some differences in orientation depending on the mode of locomotion.A biped is a vertical animal that walks on two legs. Humans are bipeds. Quadrupeds have a more horizontal body position and walk on four legs. Cats and rats are quadrupeds.Since this investigation is commonly used in human anatomy and physiology courses, human (biped) terminology is used for indicating directions. Quadruped terminology is included in Table 1 as a reference for those enrolled in a comparative or veterinary anatomy course.

tableData.text: Toward the head end of the biped body or the upper part of a structure; above
Away from the head end of the biped body or toward the lower part of a structure; below
Toward the front of the body; synonymous with cranial; synonymous with ventral in describing the biped body other than the head
Toward the back of the body; synonymous with caudal; synonymous with dorsal in describing the biped body other than the head
Toward the specimen’s leftImaginary line that bisects the body down the middle into right and left halves; the spine aligns with the midline
Away from the midline of the body; to the side
Toward or along the surface of the body or a structure; external
Below the surface of the body or a structure; internal
Toward the back of the body; synonymous with superior in quadrupeds or in bipeds when referring to the head; synonymous with posterior in describing the biped body other than the head
Toward the belly or abdomen of the body; synonymous with inferior in quadrupeds or in bipeds when referring to the head; synonymous with anterior in describing the biped body other than the head
Toward the head; synonymous with superior in bipeds
Toward the tail; synonymous with inferior in bipeds
Away from the point of reference, which is usually the attachment point
Near or toward the point of reference
Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions
Divides the body into equal left and right halves; often referred to as the midline or median plane
Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

pageData.question: Fruits, such as bananas or cucumbers, can be used to practice dissection techniques and interpreting anatomical directions and planes. If you were to make several deep cuts along the transverse plane of a cucumber, which of the following structures would you most likely create?

optionImg.altText: A circle cross section of cucumber.
optionImg.desc: A circle cross section of cucumber.

optionImg.altText: A longitudinal cross section of the entire length of a cucumber.
optionImg.desc: A longitudinal cross section of the entire length of a cucumber.

optionImg.altText: A diagonal cross section along the long axis of a cucumber.
optionImg.desc: A diagonal cross section along the long axis of a cucumber.

optionImg.altText: A wedge of a circle cross section of cucumber.
optionImg.desc: A wedge of a circle cross section of cucumber.

optionImg.altText: A quarter wedge of a longitudinal cross section of the entire length of a cucumber.
optionImg.desc: A quarter wedge of a longitudinal cross section of the entire length of a cucumber.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A deep cut goes below the surface of the body/structure, while the transverse plane is perpendicular to the long axis. Therefore, you should expect to create circular cross sections of cucumber.

pageData.question: To divide the human body into equal left and right halves, along which of the following planes would you cut?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The midsagittal plane follows the midline of the human body and divides it into equal left and right halves.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An organism can be divided into different planes. Although these planes may appear to be different for a biped versus a quadruped, they divide these types of organisms in the same manner. For example, the frontal plane (shown in Figure 1 in blue) divides both bipeds and quadrupeds into front and back halves, even though these planes are not in the same position for each organism type.
hintData.alt: Figure 1. Body planes in a cat and a human.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An organism can be divided into different planes. Although these planes may appear to be different for a biped versus a quadruped, they divide these types of organisms in the same manner. For example, the frontal plane (shown in Figure 1 in blue) divides both bipeds and quadrupeds into front and back halves, even though these planes are not in the same position for each organism type.

pageData.text: The body may be described as having two major regions:

text: The <button class=glossary-text >axial region</button> is composed of the head, neck, and trunk. (The tail of the rat is also considered part of the axial region.)
The <button class=glossary-text >appendicular region</button> consists of all four limbs.

pageData.text: Cavities are spaces within the that contain organs (see Figure 2). The dorsal cavity is formed by the bones of the cranium and spinal column. It’s subdivided into the cranial cavity, which houses the brain, and the spinal cavity, which contains the spinal cord.The is subdivided by a dome-shaped sheet of muscle called the into the and the abdominopelvic cavity. The thoracic cavity (see on the next page) contains the lungs, heart, and associated large blood vessels, together with much of the . A surrounds each lung. The pleural cavity is a thin, fluid-filled space between two membranes: the , which adheres to the surface of each lung, and the , which adheres to the chest wall.

pageData.altText: Figure 2. Diagram of the body cavities
pageData.desc: Figure 2. Diagram of the body cavities

pageData.text: The shown in Figure 3 is not a cavity. This term is given to the region within the containing the , , heart and large associated vessels, , lungs, serous membranes, nerves, and lymph nodes.The is subdivided into the and the (see ). The abdominal cavity contains the , , , and gallbladder, , and most of the . A prominent feature of the abdominal cavity is the , an apron-like serous membrane heavily invested with blood vessels. Within the mesentery are suspended various organs of the digestive system. The pelvic cavity contains the , of the large intestine, and reproductive organs.

pageData.altText: Figure 3. Diagram of the thoracic cavity and associated structures
pageData.desc: Figure 3. Diagram of the thoracic cavity and associated structures

pageData.question: Which of the following structures of the human body would be found in the thoracic cavity?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The thoracic cavity is superior to the diaphragm and contains organs such as the heart and lungs.

pageData.question: Which of the following structures of the human body would be found in the thoracic cavity?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The thoracic cavity is superior to the diaphragm and contains organs such as the heart and lungs.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Body cavities are spaces that contain organs. The human body can be divided along the frontal plane into two major cavities, the dorsal and ventral cavities. The dorsal cavity can be subdivided into the cranial cavity and the spinal cavity, which house the brain and the spinal cord, respectively. The ventral cavity can be subdivided into two smaller cavities separated by the diaphragm muscle: the thoracic cavity, which houses organs like the trachea, heart and lungs, and the abdominopelvic cavity, which contains most of the organs of the digestive, urinary, and reproductive systems.

img.alt: Figure 2. Diagram of the body cavities

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Body cavities are spaces that contain organs. The human body can be divided along the frontal plane into two major cavities, the dorsal and ventral cavities. The dorsal cavity can be subdivided into the cranial cavity and the spinal cavity, which house the brain and the spinal cord, respectively. The ventral cavity can be subdivided into two smaller cavities separated by the diaphragm muscle: the thoracic cavity, which houses organs like the trachea, heart and lungs, and the abdominopelvic cavity, which contains most of the organs of the digestive, urinary, and reproductive systems.

img.alt: Figure 2. Diagram of the body cavities

pageData.subTitle: Abdominopelvic Quadrants and Regions
pageData.text: In human anatomy, the <button class=glossary-text >abdominopelvic cavity</button> can also be subdivided into four quadrants (see Figure 4) or nine regions (see Figure 5). There are only minor variations in the placement of the various organs between the human and the rat.

pageData.altText: Figure 4. Abdominal Regions; Shutterstock ID 241069693; Purchase Order: 744680; GL Account: 38020.50116; Account Code: 580500; Project Name: Organ Systems and Terminology
pageData.desc: Figure 4. Abdominal Regions; Shutterstock ID 241069693; Purchase Order: 744680; GL Account: 38020.50116; Account Code: 580500; Project Name: Organ Systems and Terminology

pageData.altText: Figure 5. The nine abdominopelvic regions

pageData.subTitle: Organ Systems
pageData.text: The mammalian is made up of organ systems, each with a specific role in maintaining life (see ). Each organ system consists of a group of organs that operate collectively to carry out certain body functions. At every level of organization—whether at the cellular, tissue, organ, or organ-system level—each structure always reflects its function and vice versa. This concept is known as the .The mammalian body contains 11 organ systems. These organ systems do not operate independently but rather are coordinated for the organism to survive. The interdependence of organ systems needed for — the dynamic equilibrium the body sustains when in good health—must be considered and understood.

tableData.text: Barrier between body and its external environment; protective, sensory, and excretory functions
Supports body, protects internal organs, provides attachments for skeletal muscles
Pumps blood through the body for exchange of nutrients, wastes, and respiratory gases
Nasal cavities, pharynx, trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, lungs
Acquires oxygen and expels carbon dioxide
Oral cavity, esophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine, liver, gallbladder, pancreas
Takes in nutrients and eliminates waste
White blood cells and organs that produce and/or house them: bone marrow, thymus; tonsils, adenoids, spleen, appendix, Peyer’s patches, lymph nodes, and lymphatic vessels
Discriminates between self and nonself and protects the body against foreign invaders; lymphatic vessels return extracellular fluid to the bloodstream
Provides rapid control of other organ systems via neurotransmitters and nerve impulses
Hypothalamus, pituitary gland, pineal gland, pancreas, thyroid, parathyroid glands, adrenal glands, gonads
Provides slow, sustained control of other organ systems via hormones
Removes and excretes waste from blood

Male: Testes, epididymides, vasa deferentia, ejaculatory duct, urethra, penis, prostate gland, bulbourethral glands
Female: Ovaries, oviducts (Fallopian tubes, uterine tubes), uterus, vagina
tableData.hoverText:
Male: Testes, epididymides, vasa deferentia, ejaculatory duct, urethra, penis, prostate gland, bulbourethral glands
Female: Ovaries, oviducts (Fallopian tubes, uterine tubes), uterus, vagina

pageData.text: Refer to the labeled figures on the Rat Dissection Mat included in this investigation as you review each rat organ system here.
Select each tab to continue

content.text: You will not directly examine the nervous system in this investigation, but you will locate certain external sensory structures that collect information about the environment that is conveyed to the brain.Rats have fairly prominent external ears, or pinnae (singular, ), that direct sound waves toward the interior of the ear. The rat has a very sensitive sense of hearing, much more sensitive than that of humans.Each eye is protected by an outer eyelid plus a translucent inner eyelid called the , which keeps the eye moist and protected while still admitting some light. Rats have relatively poor vision compared to that of humans. However, they have (singular, vibrissa), or whiskers—sensory structures not found in humans. These specialized hairs on the face of the rat function in tactile (touch and pressure) sensation, allowing rats to find their way and detect objects even in darkness.

Like humans, rats have nostrils, or (singular, naris), that provide openings to the nasal cavities. The nasal cavities contain the sensory receptors for olfaction (the sense of smell); they also help to filter, warm, and moisten inhaled air.The (throat) serves both the respiratory system and the digestive system. Air passes through the pharynx to the (windpipe), a tube reinforced with rings of cartilage so that it remains open at all times. As you will see in the discussion of the digestive system, the pharynx also conveys food to the , a muscular tube that parallels the trachea.The trachea separates into left and right bronchi (singular, bronchus), which enter the lungs. The bulk of each lung is composed of tiny, capillary-covered air sacs that are too small to be seen without a microscope. Each lung lies within its own lined with a membrane called pleura, which secretes a lubricating fluid that protects the lungs from friction as they inflate and deflate.

The heart is the central pump of the cardiovascular system. This medially located, muscular organ lies within the pericardial cavity. The pericardium is the membrane that encloses the heart. It secretes a lubricating fluid that helps protect the heart from friction generated as it beats.

Although the endocrine system is just as important for maintaining as the nervous system, only a few endocrine glands will be examined in this investigation. Overlying the heart is the , which plays an important role in the development of the immune system. The thymus is relatively large in younger rats and shrinks with age.Certain endocrine glands are considered to belong to another organ system as well. For example, the belongs to the digestive system as well as the endocrine system. As an endocrine gland, it releases hormones into the bloodstream that regulate the storage and release of glucose. The (sex organs), which belong to the reproductive system, also function as endocrine glands. The hormones they produce regulate the development and function of other reproductive organs.

The digestive system begins with the oral cavity, which contains for biting and chewing. The rat has four long, sharp (the front teeth) that are constantly ground down by gnawing; therefore, they must continue to grow throughout the animal’s life. There are also 12 molars with broader chewing surfaces. The assists in chewing and swallowing. It is composed of skeletal muscle covered with epithelium and is attached to the floor of the oral cavity. The is the roof of the oral cavity and serves to keep the contents of the mouth out of the nasal cavities. It consists of two parts: the anterior, bony portion is the and the posterior, muscular portion is the .Just caudal to the oral cavity is the , commonly called the throat, which provides a passageway for both the digestive and respiratory systems. The is a muscular tube that conveys swallowed food from the pharynx to the .In the stomach, food is chemically and mechanically digested into a substance called chyme and passed to the . The stomach has four regions: the , which receives food from the esophagus; the pouch-like ; the ; and the , which empties into the small intestine.The small intestine is the part of the digestive system where most of the nutrient absorption occurs; therefore, its internal area is quite large. The small intestine is named for its small diameter relative to that of the . It is actually the longer of the two structures. The initial portion of the small intestine is the . This is where bile from the and pancreatic juice (see below) are added to the chyme as it enters from the stomach. The next portion is the . The terminal portion is the , which empties into the large intestine. The junction of the ileum and the large intestine is the . It contains symbiotic microorganisms that break down cellulose from ingested plant material. In humans, there is a small, fingerlike projection from the cecum called the vermiform appendix. Rats lack an appendix. In fact, the rat cecum is relatively long compared to that of a human.The liver and are the accessory organs of the digestive system. Their secretions are added to the chyme to promote digestion. The liver is the largest organ of the and is the largest internal organ of the body. It detoxifies the blood, breaks down hemoglobin, converts ammonia to urea, stores glucose as glycogen, and produces bile to aid digestion. In humans, a small greenish saclike organ called the gallbladder is nestled in the dorsal region of the liver. It stores and concentrates bile and then releases it into the small intestine. Rats lack a gallbladder, so bile produced by the liver passes directly into the small intestine. The pancreas, which belongs to the endocrine system as well, secretes enzyme-rich pancreatic juice.The large intestine is named for its wider diameter rather than its overall length. Water is absorbed from undigested food in the large intestine and compacted into feces. The large intestine includes the segments of the . The runs cranially, crosses over as the , and runs caudally as the . The terminal portion of the large intestine is the . Feces are passed from the rectum through the .

The paired kidneys filter the blood and produce urine. Each is connected to the by a tube called a . The bladder is a saclike organ that stores urine until it is released from the via the orifice of the .

The of the female rat are the ovaries. They produce eggs as well as the sex hormones estrogen and progesterone. When an egg is released from an , it enters an (also called a Fallopian tube or uterine tube) and passes to the (womb) where, if fertilized, will undergo embryonic growth and development. The rat uterus, residing in the dorsal , is Y-shaped—a is located cranially near each ovary. The two uterine horns converge at a broad, curved region called the . The fundus narrows caudally into the . The most caudal portion of the uterus is the . The cervix opens into the , the copulatory organ of the female rat that receives the of the male during mating. The vagina also serves as the birth canal. Externally, the female can be distinguished from the male by the presence of (nipples) on her abdomen. Unlike many other male mammals, male rats lack teats. In addition, the female has separate openings for the urinary and reproductive systems—the and the .The gonads of the male rat are the testes, where sperm and the sex hormone testosterone are produced. The testes are quite large and prominent in a mature male rat. The testes are housed outside the in the . The conveys sperm from the testis toward the , which serves both the urinary and reproductive systems in the male. The penis is the male copulatory organ that delivers sperm into the female reproductive tract during mating. Its tip is covered by the foreskin, or . The urethra runs the length of the penis. The , through which both urine and sperm exit the , is located at the tip of the penis.

The lymphatic/immune system will not be examined in depth in this investigation. You will encounter the <button class=glossary-text >spleen</button>, which breaks down red blood cells that have reached the end of their life span and helps monitor the bloodstream for invasion by microbes. The <button class=glossary-text >thymus</button> (as discussed as part of the endocrine system) is considered to be part of the lymphatic/immune system as well because it plays a key role in the development of immunity.

pageData.question: Which of the following rat organs belongs to more than one organ system?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The pancreas belongs to the digestive system as well as the endocrine system.

pageData.question: The thymus is an organ of the endocrine system as well as which other organ system?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The thymus is also considered part of the immune system because of its important role in immune system development.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A few endocrine glands will be examined as you dissect a preserved rat in this investigation. One of these is the thymus, which is also part of the immune system; it is superior to the heart and plays an important role in immune system development. Another endocrine gland is the pancreas, which is also part of the digestive system; one of its major functions is to regulate the storage and release of glucose into the bloodstream. You will also observe the gonads, or sex organs, which also belong to the reproductive system; they produce hormones that regulate the development and function of other reproductive organs.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A few endocrine glands will be examined as you dissect a preserved rat in this investigation. One of these is the thymus, which is also part of the immune system; it is superior to the heart and plays an important role in immune system development. Another endocrine gland is the pancreas, which is also part of the digestive system; one of its major functions is to regulate the storage and release of glucose into the bloodstream. You will also observe the gonads, or sex organs, which also belong to the reproductive system; they produce hormones that regulate the development and function of other reproductive organs.

pageData.altText:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation.
In Activity 1, you will practice interpreting directional terms and using your dissection tools by dissecting a vegetable specimen. 
In Activity 2, you will examine the external structures of the preserved rat specimen.  
In Activity 3, you will open the ventral body cavity of the rat specimen and examine its internal structures.
pageData.desc:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
In Activity 1, you will practice interpreting directional terms and using your dissection tools by dissecting a vegetable specimen. 
In Activity 2, you will examine the external structures of the preserved rat specimen.  
In Activity 3, you will open the ventral body cavity of the rat specimen and examine its internal structures.

content.title: Dissecting Set
content.text: Before beginning the dissection, familiarize yourself with the tools you will be using (see Table 3). Lay them out and within easy reach during the dissection. After you have completed the investigation, or if you are completing the investigation in stages, wash your instruments with soap and water. Be careful of sharp points and edges. When dry, store tools in the appropriate bag or case.

tableData.text: May be wood or metal; used to hold back or tease apart tissues
Used for grasping and pulling tissues

tableData.hoverText: Small 4 1/2-inch scissors made of stainless steel with one sharp and one blunt arm

tableData.text: Used for cutting tissue and making precise incisions
Has a very sharp blade used for cutting tissue
Used to keep specimen and tissues in place by pinning them to the dissection tray; may also be used to indicate specific structures for identification

Permanent marker

This investigation requires safety goggles, disposable gloves, and a lab apron.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Follow the instructions for this activity closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including using appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE); safety glasses or goggles, gloves, and a lab apron must be worn when dissecting. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing the dissection. Use proper hygiene practices before, during, and after the lab, including washing your hands before and after performing the dissection. Review pertinent portions of any Safety Data Sheets before beginning the activity. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) is flammable. Keep away from open flame if using alcohol as a disinfectant.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

pageData.text: Dissections require special attention to safety. Please follow these additional precautions:

• Clean the counter or workspace thoroughly before and after the dissection, using isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant).
  • Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the dissection.
  • Only perform the dissection on the dissection tray. This will contain both the specimen and any excess fluids.
  • Spread the absorbent pad blue side down underneath the tray to capture any spilled fluid.
  • In general, scissors are used more frequently than the scalpel, especially when care must be taken not to cut too deeply into the specimen. View the video.
  • Scalpels are used infrequently in most dissection labs and require special handling and disposal. View the video.
    • Never cut toward your holding hand and fingers.
    • Cut in a downward motion using a steady, even pressure.
    • Always use a sharp blade.
    • Do not use a scalpel that is nicked, bent, or damaged.
    • Do not use a scalpel to cut through bone or heavy cartilage.
    • Never use a scalpel for anything other than dissection.

pageData.subTitle: Carolina’s Perfect Solution®
pageData.text: Independent, certified laboratory analyses of specimens fixed in Carolina’s Perfect Solution® have found that it is nontoxic and does not give off dangerous fumes. This means that, for safety purposes, use of Carolina’s Perfect Solution® specimens does not require specialized ventilation. Carolina does recommend performing the dissection in a well-ventilated room with some active ventilation when working with any preserved specimens. For a home setting, this may include opening windows and turning on a ceiling fan. The safe nature of Carolina’s Perfect Solution® also means that, in most localities, there are no mandated disposal requirements.
Carolina’s Perfect Solution® causes mild skin irritation if suitable PPE is not worn. Avoid contact with skin and eyes. Do not ingest the specimen, especially if you are or may become pregnant.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.subTitle: Storage of Specimens
pageData.text: If it is necessary to store the specimen between work periods, you may choose to place it in the plastic storage bag with as much of the original solution as possible. Establishing an airtight seal is the best way to retain specimen integrity and prevent drying out of the specimen. First, squeeze as much air out of the specimen bag as possible before securing the opening with a rubber band, tape, or a binder clip. After closing the bag, the specimen can be stored in a larger, airtight box or bag at room temperature.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: If you were to place yourself in the “anatomical position”, which of the following would best describe your body’s position?

options.text: The body is erect, arms at the sides, palms facing forward, feet spaced slightly apart.
The body is inverted, arms lifted above the head, palms facing one another, feet spaced widely apart.
The body is erect, arms lifted above the head, palms facing one another, feet spaced slightly apart.
The body is leaning forward, arms at the sides, palms facing backward, feet spaced slightly apart.
The body is leaning backward, arms crossed on the chest, feet touching one another.

During a paintball game, your friend is hit with several paint pellets – two to the back, one to abdomen, and another to the helmet. Which of the following best describes the region of your friend’s body where paint can be found?

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a safety concern of the specimen preserved in Carolina’s Perfect Solution® used in this investigation?

assestmentData.question: Which of the following scenarios describes inappropriate handling of a scalpel?

Sara disposes of her scalpel upon noticing the blade has dulled.
Yolanda uses the scalpel to make a small incision, then scissors to enlarge it.
Tracy keeps the scalpel blade sheathed when it is not in use.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes proper storage of the preserved rat specimen between work periods?

options.text: The specimen is placed in its storage bag with as little air as possible.
The specimen is placed on the foam tray in the refrigerator.
The specimen is placed in a jar with as much of the original solution as possible.
The specimen is placed on the absorbent pad at room temperature to dry out.
The specimen is placed in an opaque container.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Review the instructions for each activity. You may wish to print out the dissection procedure to avoid getting fluid from the specimen on your computer or mobile device.
Clean the work area. Put on your PPE—safety goggles, gloves, and a lab apron—and keep them on during the dissection and cleanup.
Lay the pad on the work area with the white, absorbent side facing up.
Lay out the contents of your dissection set on the pad.
Inspect the scalpel. Do not use the scalpel if it is bent, nicked, or damaged.
Place the dissection tray in the middle of the pad to absorb any fluid that might spill onto the work area.
Position the dissection mat so you can easily view it.
In Activity 1, you will practice interpreting directional terms and using your dissection tools by dissecting a vegetable specimen.

pages.title:
A
 Directional Terms and Introduction to Dissection Techniques (9 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Directional Terms and Introduction to Dissection Techniques (9 steps)

typeBefore.text: The terms introduced in <button class=resource-text>Table 1</button> and <button class=resource-text>Figure 1</button> will be used throughout the following dissection activities. Before you make your first incision, it is important to be fully comfortable with those terms as well as the methods of handling the various dissection tools. This first activity will serve to make you comfortable using both terminology and tools together in a dissection of a cucumber.

pageData.text: Use the permanent marker to designate the <button class=glossary-text >body</button> planes on the cucumber. Assume that the cucumber represents a quadruped. Draw the following symbols on the cucumber to represent the corresponding anatomical terms:

text: Draw a circle at one end to represent the cranial region of the “specimen.”
Draw an X at the opposite end, representing the caudal region.
Draw a square in the center of the cucumber to represent the ventral side.

pageData.text: Arrange your cucumber specimen in the dissection tray in the standard <button class=glossary-text >anatomical position</button>: dorsal-side down and ventral-side up. Use rubber bands to secure the cucumber by looping one around the cranial end and behind the tray and the other around the caudal end and behind the tray.
Using the scalpel, make a superficial incision (just through the skin) starting 5 cm caudal to the cranial end along the midsagittal plane, stopping 5 cm anterior to the caudal end.
Make two superficial, lateral incisions—one sinistral and one dextral—along the frontal plane, starting 5 cm caudal to the cranial end and ending 5 cm cranial to the caudal end.

On the sinistral side 5 cm caudal to the cranial end, make a deep transverse incision toward the dextral side until you reach the midline. Make a similar deep incision from the dextral side to the midline.

At the sinistral side of the frontal plane 5 cm cranial to the caudal end, make a deep transverse incision toward the dextral side. Make a similar deep incision in the dextral side of the frontal plane, toward the sinistral side. There should be a deep outline of a rectangle in the ventral region of your cucumber.
Make a deep incision along the midsagittal plane, following the same path as the initial, superficial incision. Now the rectangle should be bisected and easy to remove.

Use the probe to fully separate the two pieces of cucumber flesh from the ventral side of the specimen, revealing the pulp and seeds within (see Figure 6). Take a picture. Notice how the skin of the cucumber is superficial to the flesh and the how the seeds and pulp are deep to the flesh.
pageData.altText: camera symbol
Figure 6. A dissected cucumber

pageData.text: Remove the rubber band securing the cranial end of your specimen. Starting 1 cm caudal to the cranial end, use the ruler to mark a series of 4 lines, 0.5 cm apart along the transverse plane. Use the scalpel to cut deeply along the transverse plane at each of these lines, passing completely through the specimen, creating cross sections of the cranial end. Take a picture. Observe the spatial relationships between the skin, flesh, and seeds and pulp. Assess whether all the cross sections are identical to one another.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In Activity 2, you will examine the external structures of the preserved rat specimen.

typeBefore.text: In Activities 2 and 3, numbers in parentheses refer to numbered structures on the Carolina® Rat Dissection Mat. Some structures are not shown on the dissection mat, but instructions are provided for their locations. Take pictures showing the listed structures. Heed any additional instructions provided by your instructor on what structures should be depicted in your photos.

pageData.text: Identify the axial and appendicular regions of the rat <button class=glossary-text >body</button>, and compare them to those of a human body. Note the tail, which is considered part of the <button class=glossary-text >axial region</button>.
Using the dissection mat as a guide, identify the manus (4) at the distal end of the forelimb and pes (6) at the distal end of each hindlimb.
Refer to the dissection mat to determine if the rat is male or female.

text: If the rat has (11) on its abdomen,then it is a female. Locate the (1) at the caudal end of the rat. The (13) of the female is cranial to the anus, and the (10) is separate from and cranial to the vaginal orifice.

A male rat will have a pouch called the (9) located cranial to the anus. It contains the testes (31). Cranial to the scrotum, most of the , the copulatory organ, lies beneath skin and fur along the ventral surface of the abdomen. The tip of the penis is shielded from view by the (8). The (12) is located at the tip of the penis.

pageData.text: Examine the external structures of the head: the pinnae (7), (14), and external (2). Use the forceps to gently open the outer eyelid if closed and observe the translucent (5).

Gently open the jaws to view the oral cavity. If the jaws prove too stiff, use the closed tip of the scissors to gently pry them apart. It may be necessary to use the scissors to make deep incisions through each cheek at the corners of the mouth. Avoid cutting into the roof of the oral cavity.
  1. Locate the (3) and the , which can be grasped with the forceps for closer examination.
  2. Use your probe to press on the roof of the mouth so you can detect the difference between the more anteriorly located and the posterior .
  3. The is just caudal to the oral cavity. It is easily detected by slipping a blunt probe to the back of the oral cavity and into the pharynx.

In Activity 3, you will open the ventral cavity of the rat specimen and examine its internal structures. Recall that the numbers in parentheses refer to numbered structures on the Carolina® Rat Dissection Mat.

pages.title:
A
 Opening and Examining the Ventral Body Cavity (3 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Opening and Examining the Ventral Body Cavity (3 steps)

pageData.text: Now you will open and begin your examination of the ventral <button class=glossary-text >body</button> cavity. Remember to take pictures of the listed structures. Heed any additional instructions provided by your instructor on what structures should be depicted in your photos.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

text: Secure the rat in the standard <button class=glossary-text >anatomical position</button> on the dissection tray using rubber bands.

Pinch the skin underneath the lower jaw with your forceps, and use your fingers to lift the skin away from the body. There may already be an opening at the throat because of the process used to preserve the specimen. If an opening is present, simply grasp the skin below the incision and use the scissors to make a superficial incision into the lifted skin. Use the forceps or your fingers to keep the skin pulled away from the body as you cut to prevent making deep incisions that could damage internal organs. Continue the incision along the midsagittal plane to just cranial to the <button class=glossary-text >prepuce</button> if the specimen is male or to the <button class=glossary-text >urethral orifice</button> if the specimen is female.

Make two lateral incisions at the collarbones and the forelimbs, as shown on the dissection mat. Repeat the lateral incisions at the hips, tracing the hind limbs. Use the closed scissors to carefully separate the skin from the fascia (the white connective tissue between the skin and the underlying muscle). Be careful to not cut into the underlying structures.

Make an incision in the now-exposed muscles of the abdominal wall in the pubic region, being careful to not cut into the underlying organs. Use the forceps to lift the muscle layer and cut from the pubic region to the bottom of the rib cage. Make two lateral cuts through the rib cage and a third cut to the throat through the flat breastbone, or sternum, located in the midline. The <button class=glossary-text >diaphragm</button> (16) should be visible as a thin, muscular sheet attached to the inferior boundary of the rib cage. Cut the diaphragm away, and lift the ribs to view the underlying organs.

Beginning with the cranial, superficial structures and progressing to caudal, deeper structures, examine the contents of the <button class=glossary-text >thoracic cavity</button>. Use the dissection mat as a guide. Take note of relationships between structures belonging to the same organ system.

pageData.text: First, examine each of the thoracic cavity structures described below.

text: The <button class=glossary-text >trachea</button> (35) runs medially from the <button class=glossary-text >pharynx</button> and then separates into left and right bronchi, which enter the lungs (23).

Use the probe to move the trachea to one side to view the <button class=glossary-text >esophagus</button> (18). Notice that the esophagus is dorsal to the trachea and, unlike the trachea, is not reinforced with cartilage.

Find the medially located oval heart (19). The space it occupies is the pericardial cavity. The glandular tissue overlying the heart is the <button class=glossary-text >thymus</button> (32). Use forceps to move the thymus aside to more clearly view the heart.
There is a lung (23) lateral to the left and right sides of the heart. Notice the spongy texture. The space occupied by each lung is its <button class=glossary-text >pleural cavity</button>.

The diaphragm is a thin, muscular sheet attached to the caudal boundary of the rib cage; it separates the thoracic cavity from the <button class=glossary-text >abdominal cavity</button>. Notice that the esophagus must pass through the diaphragm to convey food to the <button class=glossary-text >stomach</button> (32).

pageData.text: Proceed to examine the structures of the <button class=glossary-text >abdominopelvic cavity</button>.

text: The <button class=glossary-text >liver</button> (22) is the large, brownish-red organ located directly caudal to the diaphragm.

The curved stomach lies sinistrally in the abdominal cavity, just caudal to the liver. Locate the portion of the stomach that is connected to the esophagus. This is the <button class=glossary-text >cardiac region</button>. The pouch-like portion extending sinistrally is the <button class=glossary-text >fundus</button>, and the funnel-shaped region that empties into the <button class=glossary-text >small intestine</button> (28) is the <button class=glossary-text >pylorus</button>. The remainder of the stomach is its body.

Use the forceps to lift the stomach, revealing the dorsally located <button class=glossary-text >pancreas</button> (26). The membrane in which the pancreas rests is the <button class=glossary-text >mesentery</button> (24).
The <button class=glossary-text >spleen</button> (31) is an elongated, dark-red organ that curves around the caudal and sinistral region of the stomach.

The small intestine (30) is the tubelike structure that joins the pylorus of the stomach to the <button class=glossary-text >large intestine</button> (21). The first, C-shaped segment of the small intestine after the pylorus is the <button class=glossary-text >duodenum</button>; the segment adjacent to the beginning of the large intestine is the <button class=glossary-text >ileum</button>. In between is the middle portion, the tightly coiled <button class=glossary-text >jejunum</button>.
The <button class=glossary-text >cecum</button> (15) is the pouch-like junction of the ileum and the large intestine.

The large intestine (21) lies superficial to the small intestine. The large intestine includes the segments of the <button class=glossary-text >colon</button>, which can be partially identified by their initial position upon opening the abdominal cavity. The <button class=glossary-text >ascending colon</button> runs cranially toward the stomach, crosses over sinistrally as the <button class=glossary-text >transverse colon</button>, and runs dorsally and caudally as the <button class=glossary-text >descending colon</button>. The terminal portion of the large intestine is the <button class=glossary-text >rectum</button>. Locate the rectum by carefully inserting a blunt probe a short distance into the <button class=glossary-text >anus</button>.
Use forceps to move the stomach and intestines aside to reveal the deeper abdominal structures. (You may remove the cecum if desired, as shown on the back of the dissection mat.)

Locate the pair of kidneys (20). These bean-shaped organs are on either side of the caudal abdominal cavity. Connected to each <button class=glossary-text >kidney</button> is a tube called a <button class=glossary-text >ureter</button>. Each ureter connects caudally to the saclike <button class=glossary-text >urinary bladder</button> (36). The <button class=glossary-text >urethra</button>, which conveys urine from the body, was observed via its external opening [male (12), female (10)] in Activity 2, Step 3 when the sex of the rat was determined.

If your specimen is male, make a superficial incision into the (9) as shown on the dissection mat. Loosen and lift out the oval testis (31). Gently pull on the testis to identify the (36). Locate the prostate gland (28) and the seminal vesicle (29).If your specimen is female, inspect the dorsal to identify the Y-shaped with its paired (37). The broad, curved, cranial part of the uterus is the fundus. Here, the most cranial portion of each uterine horn narrows into an . The oviducts extend cranially and laterally toward the female , the (25). The narrow, more caudal section of the uterus is the , and the most caudal section, which opens into the , is the . You examined the (13) when you determined the rat’s sex.

pageData.text: Dispose of any excess fluids down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for about 30 seconds to dilute the fluids.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: Place the specimen in its storage bag and seal tightly. If you are finished working with your specimen, put the bag into an opaque trash bag for disposal in the household garbage.
Rinse and carefully air-dry the dissection tools, and return the materials to your equipment kit.

Sanitize the work space with isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant) and paper towels. If this is insufficient for removing grease during cleanup, use soap and water, followed by more alcohol/disinfectant.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.altText: completion

pageData.text: Insert the photo of the labeled vegetable specimen. The circle and “X” marking the cranial and caudal ends of the specimen should be visible in the photo. If they are not, add labels to the photo prior to uploading.
Click on the browse button to upload the file

pageData.title: Questions
text: In Activity 1, which layer of the cucumber was the most superficial: the skin, the flesh, or the seeds and pulp? Which layer was the deepest? (Note: If you used a banana, the only layers would be the skin and the flesh. Commercially available bananas do not have seeds.)
In Activity 1, step 9, you created a series of cross-sections. Were they all identical with one another? Explain your answer.

pageData.text:
Insert the photo of the ventral view of the rat. The specimen should be labeled “female” or “male” in the photo before uploading, depending on its sex. The following should also be indicated in this photo:
  • Naris
  • Incisor
  • Vibrissa
  • Manus
  • Pes
  • Anus (if visible—in a male, it may be obscured by the scrotum)
  • If female:
    • Teat
    • Vaginal orifice
    • Urethral orifice
  • If male:
    • Scrotum
    • Prepuce
    • Urogenital opening
Click on the browse button to upload the file

Insert the photo(s) of the ventral body cavity of the rat. The following structures should be indicated:
  • Trachea
  • Esophagus
  • Thymus
  • Heart
  • Lung
  • Diaphragm
  • Liver
  • Stomach
  • Spleen
  • Small intestine
  • Large intestine
  • Kidney
  • Ureter
  • Urinary bladder
  • If female:
    • Uterine horno
    • Ovary
  • If male:
    • Testis

tableData.text: Toward the head end of the biped body or the upper part of a structure; above
Away from the head end of the biped body or toward the lower part of a structure; below
Toward the front of the body; synonymous with cranial; synonymous with ventral in describing the biped body other than the head
Toward the back of the body; synonymous with caudal; synonymous with dorsal in describing the biped body other than the head
Toward the specimen’s leftImaginary line that bisects the body down the middle into right and left halves; the spine aligns with the midline
Away from the midline of the body; to the side
Toward or along the surface of the body or a structure; external
Below the surface of the body or a structure; internal
Toward the back of the body; synonymous with superior in quadrupeds or in bipeds when referring to the head; synonymous with posterior in describing the biped body other than the head
Toward the belly or abdomen of the body; synonymous with inferior in quadrupeds or in bipeds when referring to the head; synonymous with anterior in describing the biped body other than the head
Toward the head; synonymous with superior in bipeds
Toward the tail; synonymous with inferior in bipeds
Away from the point of reference, which is usually the attachment point
Near or toward the point of reference
Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions
Divides the body into equal left and right halves; often referred to as the midline or median plane
Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

Table 2. Organ systems of the rat
pageData.title: Table 2.

tableData.text: Barrier between body and its external environment; protective, sensory, and excretory functions
Supports body, protects internal organs, provides attachments for skeletal muscles
Pumps blood through the body for exchange of nutrients, wastes, and respiratory gases
Nasal cavities, pharynx, trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, lungs
Acquires oxygen and expels carbon dioxide
Oral cavity, esophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine, liver, gallbladder, pancreas
Takes in nutrients and eliminates waste
White blood cells and organs that produce and/or house them: bone marrow, thymus; tonsils, adenoids, spleen, appendix, Peyer’s patches, lymph nodes, and lymphatic vessels
Discriminates between self and nonself and protects the body against foreign invaders; lymphatic vessels return extracellular fluid to the bloodstream
Provides rapid control of other organ systems via neurotransmitters and nerve impulses
Hypothalamus, pituitary gland, pineal gland, pancreas, thyroid, parathyroid glands, adrenal glands, gonads
Provides slow, sustained control of other organ systems via hormones
Removes and excretes waste from blood

Male: Testes, epididymides, vasa deferentia, ejaculatory duct, urethra, penis, prostate gland, bulbourethral glands
Female: Ovaries, oviducts (Fallopian tubes, uterine tubes), uterus, vagina
tableData.hoverText:
Male: Testes, epididymides, vasa deferentia, ejaculatory duct, urethra, penis, prostate gland, bulbourethral glands
Female: Ovaries, oviducts (Fallopian tubes, uterine tubes), uterus, vagina

pageData.altText:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
In Activity 1, you will practice interpreting directional terms and using your dissection tools by dissecting a vegetable specimen. 
In Activity 2, you will examine the external structures of the preserved rat specimen.  
In Activity 3, you will open the ventral body cavity of the rat specimen and examine its internal structures.

tableData.text: May be wood or metal; used to hold back or tease apart tissues
Used for grasping and pulling tissues

tableData.hoverText: Small 4 1/2-inch scissors made of stainless steel with one sharp and one blunt arm

tableData.text: Used for cutting tissue and making precise incisions
Has a very sharp blade used for cutting tissue
Used to keep specimen and tissues in place by pinning them to the dissection tray; may also be used to indicate specific structures for identification

pageData.altText: Figure 6. A dissected cucumber
pageData.content: Figure 6. Ventral view of dissected cucumber

data.title: Abdominal cavity
data.content: Contains the stomach, small intestine, pancreas, liver, gallbladder, spleen, and most of the large intestine

data.title: Abdominopelvic cavity
data.content: Largest hollow space of the body, upper boundary is the diaphragm, lower boundary is the  pelvic cavity

data.title: Anatomical position (standard anatomical position)
data.content: The pose in which a person is standing upright with their face forward, their arms at their sides, and their palms open, a rat in the comparable position for dissection has its abdomen facing up toward the observer

data.title: Anus
data.content: Opening where the gastrointestinal tract ends and waste exits the body

data.title: Appendicular region
data.content: Consists of all four limbs

data.title: Ascending colon
data.content: Located on the right side of the abdomen, runs cranially, crosses over as the transverse colon, and runs caudally as the descending colon

data.title: Axial region
data.content: Composed of the head, neck, and trunk. (the tail of the rat is also considered part of the axial region.)

data.title: Body
data.content: The largest part of an organ

data.title: Cardiac region (cardia)
data.content: Opening of the esophagus into the stomach

data.title: Cecum
data.content: Pouch that forms the first part of the large intestine

data.title: Cervix
data.content: Separates the uterus from the vagina

data.title: Colon
data.content: Longest part of the large intestine

data.title: Descending colon
data.content: Left part of the colon that passes downward

data.title: Diaphragm
data.content: A dome-shaped sheet of muscle, separates the chest cavity and abdominal cavities

data.title: Duodenum
data.content: The first portion of the small intestine

data.title: Esophagus
data.content: A muscular tube that connects the throat to the stomach

data.title: Fundus
data.content: The part of an organ that is farthest away from the organ's opening

data.title: Fundus
data.content: Located superior to the entry of the fallopian tubes

data.title: Gonads
data.content: Dedicated organs for the production of gametes

data.title: Hard palate
data.content: Anterior, bony portion of the palate

data.title: Homeostasis
data.content: Is a self-regulating process by which biological systems maintain stability while adjusting to environmental changes

data.title: Ileum
data.content: The last portion of the small intestine

data.title: Incisors
data.content: Teeth are at the front of the mouth, designed for shearing or cutting

data.title: Isthmus
data.content: A narrow connection between two larger bodies or parts

data.title: Jejunum
data.content: Middle part of the small intestine

data.title: Kidney
data.content: Two bean-shaped organs are responsible for the three processes involved in urine production

data.title: Large intestine
data.content: Tube-like organ that is connected to the small intestine at one end and the anus at the other, combines waste from the body and waste from bacteria (inhabiting our intestines) before elimination from the body

data.title: Liver
data.content: A large organ that sits on the right side of the belly, performs many important functions including; removes toxins, maintains blood sugar levels, and regulates blood clotting

data.title: Mediastinum
data.content: The region within the thoracic cavity containing the trachea, esophagus, heart and large associated vessels, thymus, lungs, serous membranes, nerves, and lymph nodes

data.title: Mesentery
data.content: Found in the abdominal cavity, an apron-like serous membrane heavily invested with blood vessels

data.title: Molar
data.content: Tooth with broader chewing surface

data.title: Nares
data.content: Nostrils, openings to the respiratory system

data.title: Nasal cavity
data.content: Found above the bone that forms the roof of the mouth, lined with a mucus-producing, ciliated epithelium, joins with the throat

data.title: Nictitating membrane
data.content: Located in the medial corner of the eye, transparent, allows for some protection and moistening without as great of a loss of vision as blinking of the eyelids

data.title: Ovary (Plural, Ovaries)
data.content: Produce female gametes (ova), found in the dorsal wall of the abdomen caudal to the kidneys

data.title: Oviduct (fallopian tubes)
data.content: Fallopian tubes transport eggs from the ovaries to the uteri

data.title: Palate
data.content: The roof of the oral cavity and serves to keep the contents of the mouth out of the nasal cavities

data.title: Pancreas
data.content: Fish-shaped organ located in the abdominal cavity

data.title: Parietal pleura
data.content: Membrane that adheres  to the chest wall

data.title: Pelvic cavity
data.content: Contains the urinary bladder, rectum of the large intestine, and reproductive organs

data.title: Penis
data.content: Male genital organ, urine and sperm both leave the body through an opening

data.title: Pharynx
data.content: The "throat", a muscular passageway

data.title: Pinna (auricle)
data.content: The outer flap of the ear

data.title: Pleural cavity
data.content: A thin, fluid-filled space between two membranes, surrounds each lung

data.title: Prepuce
data.content: Foreskin, covers the tip of the penis

data.title: Principle of Complementarity of Structure and Function
data.content: Each anatomical structure always reflects its function and vice versa

data.title: Pylorus
data.content: Empties into the small intestine

data.title: Rectum
data.content: Terminal portion of the large intestine

data.title: Scrotal sac (scrotum)
data.content: External, surrounds the testes

data.title: Small intestine
data.content: Helps to digest food coming from the stomach

data.title: Soft palate
data.content: Posterior, muscular portion of the palate

data.title: Spleen
data.content: Ductless organ that is located in the left abdominal region near the stomach, involved in the production and removal of blood cells

data.title: Stomach
data.content: A muscular organ located on the left side of the upper abdomen, receives food from the esophagus

data.title: Teat
data.content: Projection at the tip of each breast, outlet to the lactiferous ducts (mammary glands)

data.title: Thoracic cavity
data.content: Contains the lungs, heart, and associated large blood vessels, together with much of the esophagus

data.title: Thymus
data.content: Located inferior to the thyroid gland and anterior to the heart, belongs to the lymphatic, immune system, and endocrine system

data.title: Tongue
data.content: Composed of skeletal muscle covered with epithelium and is attached to the floor of the oral cavity

data.title: Tooth (teeth)
data.content: Hard, mineral-rich structure, used to chew food

data.title: Trachea
data.content: The "windpipe", a tube with C-shaped rings of cartilage, extends from the larynx to the bronchial tubes

data.title: Transverse colon
data.content: Middle portion of the colon

data.title: Ureter
data.content: Tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder

data.title: Urethra
data.content: A duct in which urine leaves the body, or as well as sperm in males

data.title: Urethral orifice
data.content: External opening of the urethra

data.title: Urinary bladder
data.content: Temporary storage for urine

data.title: Urogenital opening
data.content: Both urine and sperm exit the body, is located at the tip of the penis

data.title: Uterine horn
data.content: In the dorsal pelvic cavity, Y-shaped, located cranially near each ovary

data.title: Uterus
data.content: The area where the fertilized egg attaches itself and develops into a fetus

data.title: Vagina
data.content: Muscular tube leading from the external genitals to the cervix

data.title: Vaginal orifice
data.content: External opening to the vagina

data.title: Vas deferens (ductus deferens)
data.content: Transfers sperm from a testis to the urethra

data.title: Ventral cavity
data.content: A fluid filled space surrounding the organs on the ventral side of humans and other tetrapod's

data.title: Vibrissae
data.content: Specialized hairs, whiskers

data.title: Visceral Pleura
data.content: Membrane that adheres to the surface of each lung

kc.text: Use the Reset button to try this question again. Use the Hint button to revisit the question concept(s). After opening the hint, you will be presented with a new question to attempt. You may continue to access the hint as you answer the new question.

kc-resource.text: Use the Reset button to try this question again. Use the Hint button to revisit the question concept(s). After opening the hint, you will be presented with a new question to attempt. You may continue to access the hint as you answer the new question.You can find a complete list of the figures, tables and videos in this investigation using the Resources icon.

procedure.text: You can track completion of each step by clicking on the step number.
